message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has cryptorchidism, or undescended testis, on the left side. If left untreated, this could lead to infertility and hormonal deficiencies. Inhibin, a hormone secreted by the testicles, would likely be deficient in this patient by puberty. LH, FSH, and testosterone levels could also be affected, but inhibin is the most likely hormone to be affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description suggests an undescended testis or cryptorchidism with an associated inguinal hernia. If left untreated, testicular atrophy can occur and inhibin secretion by Sertoli cells can decrease. Inhibin can help regulate FSH secretion, leading to a deficiency of inhibin by puberty if the condition is not treated. Testosterone production may also be affected, but the primary hormone affected by this condition is inhibin. Therefore, the answer is (B) inhibin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with an undescended testis on the left side. If left untreated, the patient will likely have testicular atrophy and infertility due to lack of inhibin hormone production. Testosterone is also needed for proper sexual development but its deficiency is not specific to this condition. LH and FSH levels may be affected but are not the primary hormones involved.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The diagnosis in this case is cryptorchidism, which means the testes did not descend into the scrotum. Without prompt treatment, there will be testicular degeneration of the affected testis and they will become nonfunctional. Inhibin, which is produced by testicular tissue, will be deficient in this patient if the condition is left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of a testis in the left hemiscrotal sac suggests an undescended testis, also known as cryptorchidism. This condition can lead to infertility and increased risk for testicular cancer if left untreated. It is associated with deficient inhibin secretion by the testis which may lead to impaired spermatogenesis. LH, FSH, and testosterone levels would not necessarily be affected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests that the child has an undescended testis on the left side, which is typically associated with a deficiency in Inhibin production. If left untreated, this can lead to decreased spermatogenesis and fertility later in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation is consistent with an undescended testis on the left side. In this case, the testis remains in the abdomen and secretes inhibin, which causes negative feedback on FSH production by the anterior pituitary gland. If left untreated, there may be deficiency in inhibin secretion, resulting in increased FSH levels and decreased testosterone production by puberty. Therefore, inhibin is the hormone that would likely be deficient in this patient by puberty if the condition is left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described in the question indicate that the infant has cryptorchidism, which can cause the testes to be undescended. Inhibin is a hormone that is produced by the Sertoli cells of the testes and regulates the secretion of FSH. If left untreated, cryptorchidism can lead to a deficiency of Inhibin, which can ultimately result in impaired spermatogenesis and testosterone production. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) Inhibin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation suggests cryptorchidism, in which the testis has not descended into the scrotum. If left untreated, inhibin levels will decrease, leading to possible infertility due to testicular atrophy. The other options are involved in the production or regulation of testosterone, but it is the lack of inhibin that will lead to testicular atrophy if the condition is left untreated.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The non-reducible non-tender inguinal mass and empty scrotum suggest an undescended testis, which is commonly seen in young infants. If left untreated, inhibin hormone would likely be deficient by puberty as the testis remains undescended and doesn't receive the required stimulation for hormone production. LH, FSH, and testosterone would also be affected but inhibin is the most specific to testicular function.
